content.full_text: Receipt of J. G. Bowman to Aaron Shaw, 8 January 18461 $62.50 No.148-155 Received of theAUDITOR WARRANTon theTREASURERof theState ofIllinoisforSixty twodollars andfiftycents,infullforthe salary of ofA. Shawas States atty of4thcirct. yr. ending Decr 31/452
paragraphs: Receipt of J. G. Bowman to Aaron Shaw, 8 January 18461 $62.50 No.148-155 Received of theAUDITOR WARRANTon theTREASURERof theState ofIllinoisforSixty twodollars andfiftycents,infullforthe salary of ofA. Shawas States atty of4thcirct. yr. ending Decr 31/452
citations:
“An Act to Regulate the Time of Holding Circuit Courts in the  Fourth Judicial Circuit,”
                     1 March 1843,Laws of Illinois(1843), 133.

footnotes.text:
1J. G. Bowman filled in the blanks and signed this partially-printed document. Abraham
                  Lincoln signed his own name only.

2In 1845, the Fourth Judicial Circuit of Illinois included thirteen counties in eastern
                  and  southeastern Illinois.“An Act to Regulate the Time of Holding Circuit Courts in the  Fourth Judicial Circuit,”
                     1 March 1843,Laws of Illinois(1843), 133.
3J. G. Bowman could not be positively identified.

structured_content.text: Receipt of J. G. Bowman to Aaron Shaw, 8 January 18461

Received of theAUDITOR WARRANTon theTREASURERof theState ofIllinoisforSixty twodollars andfiftycents,infullforthe salary of ofA. Shawas States atty[attorney] of4thcirct. yr.[Year] ending Decr[December] 31/45[1845]2
